Award.AwardTitle: Cosmology in the Non-Linear Regime with Weak Gravitational Lensing
Award.AbstractNarration:
Jia Liu is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a program of research and education at Princeton University. Liu will develop theoretical models and use them to interpret observations that could provide new insight into dark energy, as well as a way to measure the total mass of neutrinos. "Dark energy" is the term for the unknown form of energy that is accelerating the expansion of the Universe. By improving constraints on key cosmological parameters, the proposed research would significantly improve our understanding of the Universe. For the education component of her work, Liu will serve as a volunteer instructor for Princeton's Prison Teaching Initiative (PTI), where she will teach college level mathematics and science courses, including a new preparatory physics and astronomy course aimed at helping inmates discover their interest in science and acquire the skills and credentials to succeed in life outside prison.

Liu will undertake N-body ray-tracing simulations to investigate non-Gaussian statistics that are essential for a proper interpretation of the weak lensing of galaxies and the cosmic microwave background. The proposed work has the potential to (1) improve constraints on the dark energy equation of state nearly twofold, thereby doubling the output of survey observations with Advanced Atacama Cosmology Telescope and the Hyper Suprime-Cam; and (2) shed light on the neutrino mass hierarchy, a long-standing problem in particle physics. It will also advance our understanding of weak lensing systematics, including photometric redshift, intrinsic alignment of galaxies, and shape measurements. Reducing noise from these systematics will further improve cosmological constraints. As a volunteer instructor at PTI, Liu will teach college level mathematics and science courses to inmates, design a new preparatory physics and astronomy course, and train other instructors to teach the newly designed course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellow, the PI investigated the cosmological information in the small, nonlinear regime with weak gravitational lensing observations, a technique that relies on the bending of light by matter to infer the distribution of matter in our Universe. She has contributed to frontier works in cosmology through: 


(1) running a large set of numerical N-body simulations, the MassiveNuS, which models the effect of massive neutrinos on structure formation. Numerical simulations are the most accurate tools to study the small scales. The MassiveNuS suite has been released to the public through http://www.columbialensing.org (20T data) and allowed not only the PI, but also independent research groups around the globe to explore novel techniques to constrain the neutrino mass sum––a major science goal for upcoming cosmological surveys.


(2) studying weak lensing non-Gaussian statistics that are particularly powerful on the small, nonlinear regime, where the usual two-point (Gaussian) statistics fail to capture all the information. Her works on weak lensing peak counts, counts of minima, one-point probability distribution function, bispectrum, and Minkowski functionals have shown that these statistics can significantly tighten the cosmological constraints. She is now leading multiple projects within the Vera Rubin Observatory LSST Dark Energy Science Collaboration to implement these techniques on the upcoming weak lensing data from LSST.


(3) investigating novel cosmological observables such as cosmic voids and halos in voids. Her theoretical works have found that voids, the emptiest regions in our Universe, contain rich information that is complementary to the more well-studied overdense regions. 


The PI was also involved in multiple outreach activities:


(1) As the math leader for the Prison Teaching Initiative, the PI coordinated the course design and instructor recruitment, training, and staffing for all math courses across New Jersey (state and federal) prisons. She taught six math classes, ranging from elementary algebra to precalculus, to groups of 6-12 inmates per class. In addition, together with 4 other volunteers, she designed and adapted a new physics lab, which is critical for the inmates to obtain science and engineering degrees. The new course has recently been deployed to the NJ state prisons.


(2) The PI advised more than ten students in three years, including both undergraduate and graduate students, resulting in six student-led publications. Two students have defended their theses, both of which include research results conducted under the supervision of the PI. 


(3) The PI has given 40+ talks at seminars, colloquia, conferences, workshops, and public outreach events to disseminate her scientific results. She also taught two summer schools at the national observatory in Rio de Janeiro in Brazil and at the dark matter summer school at University at Albany, New York. In addition, she was active in public services, serving as the organizer of the Princeton-IAS joint colloquium series, the coordinator for the Princeton arxiv daily discussion, and the organizer of the Berkeley Center for Cosmological Physics journal club.
